RView: Maya intelligent render view chooser

Posted on May 14, 2020 by joss

Problem with the current Maya “Render Image” and “IPR” buttons is that they’re bound to an old Maya Render View, while every rendering engine has it’s own RenderView now.

Idea is very simple: take current renderer and just use it’s MEL or Python commands to show appropriate RenderView or start IPR. Compatible with Arnold, Octane, V-Ray, and basically any renderer that has appropriate MEL or Python commands.

As a side function, quick preview resolution chooser has been added to right-click menu, so users can set test resolutions instantly instead of spending 10s every time. Almost no one using it just because of the not very good UI.

Posted in maya, projects, python2

Posted on May 14, 2020 by joss

Envexp is a simple PySide tool that utilizes cross-DCC loading mechanism and can transparently work in basically all software supporting Python and Qt / PySide.

The main purpose is to simplify software installation and debugging.

Here’s envexp is running inside of Maya2020, next picture shows the same code running inside of Nuke.

AWS S3 bucket tool / Python3 module

Posted on May 13, 2020 by joss

So, recently I started to look into Vcpkg ports and found that they have AWS S3 APIs, so why not to try something funny with it:
Quickly scouted the docs and built a simple S3 class supporting minimal set of bucket operations: ls(), ul(), dk(), rm(). These are more than enough to manage any S3 bucket, and it worked, but it’s not the end.

Then I took PyBind11 (and tried boost-python as well) and created a Python3 interface for the class, so now it’s possible to load a simple module into your Py3 script and have a full access to S3 bucket, without boto3 and 7 other dependencies.

Maya 2021 will support Python3, and that’s when all the fun will start: with Python3 we don’t need MSVS2008 anymore, we can use state of the art libraries without hesitation that “it won’t compile”. Just a one single statically linked .pyd file and you’re good.

Thinking on using TransferManagers now for parallel transfers in the next version.

Posted in c++, cmake, projects, python3, vcpkg

VDB Tool

Posted on May 13, 2020 by joss

VDB Tool is a quick project I decided to do over another weekend to finally employ the VDB library and understand on how to read multilayered CT scans from Tiff files (I wasn’t able to find a reader that could just display 128 layers of 1-channel float image), oh, and of course practice a little bit in kung-fu Cmake.
I succeeded, but then decided to switch from Tifflib to OCIO for image input, allowing me to basically take an iPhone video sequence and make a VDB out of it.
